She hopes that the quality of life in her country will improve, given that the help of other donor countries is so important, since it supports the people that really need it. Her main economic activity is providing taxi services, and it is located throughout the city. She has four years of experience at her work. Alba started this business as an alternative way of earning money. She got the taxi service by selling a business selling whole grains that she had in the wholesale market of Bisne in Managua and through other necessary financing arrangements. Alba didn't have a lot of knowledge about this type of business at first, so the person she hired as the driver turned in very little money and didn't distribute the earnings. With the help of her family, she managed to find a reliable person for this job. Over time, she has gained experience in the business, but she still needs the requested financing to fund the business so that she can make improvements to her vehicle, including changing the radiator, tires, and other things. She acknowledges the support of Fundación León 2000 and its sister organizations.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairs to her vehicle

loans.name: Lim's Group

texts.en:
This small loan group is made up of four members, all residents of Chong Kneas Commune, Siem Reap Province. Mrs. V. has been selected to be the group leader by the members. She is 24 years old and is married to Sat, who is also 24. The young couple makes a living by working as carriers at the fish market, and they can earn around US$ 3 per day. They currently have two children; they are both young. The family's living conditions are not so good because their house is broken frequently; thus, they both have decided to request a loan to repair their old house.

The other three borrowers are:

K. is a reserve worker and she needs a loan to purchase a motorcycle for family transport.

R. is a reserve worker, a widow, and she is requesting a loan to repair her old house.

P. is a reserve worker, a widow, and she is asking for a loan as capital to R. a new business as a grocery seller.

All four of the borrowers are working at the same place in their community.

loans.use: To repair their old house

loans.name: Chheoum

texts.en:
Chheoum S., 46, has business grinding rice crops and recharging batteries from her home in Siem Reap province. She is able to make $7 per day, while her husband, pictured here, earns $4 working as a construction foreman and renting music equipment. This couple has nine children, seven of whom are in school, while two are too young to attend.

Chhoeum S. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband for commuting to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Nub

texts.en:
Nub S., 27, is a villager living in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, where he makes a living driving a motor taxi. He also earns additional income by working at the fish market. He is a very responsible man to his family and he especially makes sure his one young child gets the highest education and enough food. His wife currently works as a garment worker.

Nub S. has requested a loan of $1000 in order to buy a trailer to connect to his existing motorcycle to provide a taxi service (Tuk Tuk). He plans to use the remainder of the loan to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy a trailer and a plot of land

loans.name: Suitupe

texts.en: Suitupe L. T. 45, is married with five children.  She has five years of experience in the pork cake and popcorn business. She sells to school children and villagers five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 125 Tala. SPBD loans are Suitupe’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase bag of flour, soya sauce , garlic onions , butter , pop corn , onions, plastic bags  and frying pan.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.ru: Сангинова Мавлуда кредитор в Микроинвест с 2002 года. Она  занимается продажей детской одежды. За товаром ездит сама, в город Истарашан. Свои кредиты погашает хорошо без проблем. Хотя замечает что торговля стала чуть медленнее. Поэтому Мавлуда получив очередной кредит хочет пополнить свой ассортимент новыми товарами. У Мавлуды остаток весенне- летнего товара осталось маловато. Она надеется , что при увеличении выбора товара у неё реализация пойдёт на рост , т.е. поток клиентов увеличится.
texts.en:
S. Mavluda is a client of MicroInvest since 2002. She is selling children's clothing. She travels for the merchandise herself to Istarashan. She pays off her loans without any problems. Although she has noticed that sales are lower now. This is why Mavluda wants to use this loan to add some new assortment to her inventory. She has a little bit of the spring-summer clothing left. She hopes that by increasing the variety and choice of her inventory she will sell it faster and the flow of customers will increase.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the assortment of goods

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn is 33 years old and she has operated a typical village store for many years. She is married to German Laggui and they were blessed with 3 children; John Mark is 12 years old and in the first year high school, Jay Jay is 11 years old and in grade school, finally John Lloyd is 5 years old also attends grade school. They currently reside at Barangay Minanga Proper, Angadanan Isabela, a rural area, approximately 4 kilometers away from the national highway.
                                  
Jonalyn is asking for a loan amounting to PHP 20,000. Her daily gross income from the business is around PHP 2,100. Beverages are the most popular item in her village and will use the loan to satisfy her customers and able to improve her business. Jonalyn added that, “when you work hard, unexpectedly you will receive more blessings”.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional film and seeds

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen has been in the media and production business for over 10 years. In 2002 she moved to New York from Florida, where she grew up, to work as an editor and producer. She eventually became a freelancer and about two years ago, with a growing client base, she decided to establish a full-service media consulting and production company. Maureen enjoys her work and is dedicated to helping non-profit organizations use media to effectively disseminate their message. 

She heard the same response from many banks, which was that they couldn’t lend to a business of her size at this time. Given that she needed capital to sustain and to help grow her business, Maureen decided to look into microfinance options and so she came to ACCION USA. With her loan, Maureen is hiring a new employee to help grow the business’ client base. She will also use a portion of the loan to cover the costs associated with developing new partnerships with other media companies to initiate new projects. 

Maureen has established her business and created a loyal clientele that depends on her for their media needs. Her long-term vision for her business is to help expand her outreach to serve more non-profits.

video.title: Kiva Entrepreneur Maureen from  United States

loans.use: Hiring a new employee and outreach

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Komi A. est un homme de 45 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants.il est conducteur de taxi à Avetonou, un village situé au sud-ouest du Togo. Komi souhaite avec ce crédit changer le moteur de sa voiture pour limiter les dépenses incessantes que lui cause sa voiture. Cette opportunité lui permettra de mieux répondre aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Komi A. is a 45 year old man, he is married and the father of 3 children. He is a taxi driver in Avetonou, a town located in southwest Togo. Komi hopes that with this loan he will replace the motor of his car, in order to limit the never ending expenses that are caused by his car. This opportunity will enable him to respond better to the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replace the motor of his car

loans.name: Vasiliy

texts.en:
Vasiliy is married with two grown-up children. He sells clothing and women's purses at the central market in Pavlograd city. He has been in this business for about three years. During this time, he has set up a first business location and started a second one. Vasiliy says that being self-employed gives him strong motivation to work hard. He enjoys his business and even has plans to start a third location.

Vasiliy would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to purchase a new collection of women's purses. He hopes to increase sales and invest money back into his business.

loans.use: To purchase women's purses

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael sells tailoring materials and has been in this business for the past four years, on her own, after training for two years. In her locality she is the only one selling tailoring materials, hence the increasing demand. She is requesting for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. Rachael is 32 years old and married with two children. She says thank you,

loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en:
Nizami is a scrap metal dealer. He is applying for his fourth loan from Komak, and this loan will be the second of his funded by Kiva lenders. (See the Kiva page for Nizami's first loan)

Nizami is enjoying his business. He needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy metals to further improve his business.

loans.use: To buy metal for a scrap metal shop.

loans.name: Zaryl's Group

texts.en:
The leader of the group, Zaryl, is fifty-three years old. Her parents used to breed livestock and Zaryl, from her early childhood, was familiar with this occupation. When she grew up, she got married and decided to continue in this activity of breeding livestock. She inherited her family’s occupation. For twenty years, she has been making a living in animal husbandry, raising livestock and selling milk products. Her spouse has been working as a gardener. They have two children: a daughter, 27, works in a pharmacy and a son, 7. Recently, Zaryl and her husband have made repairs to their house, built a shed and increased the total population of their livestock. Considering their monthly income of just $50, these are big achievements made. All this has been possible due to their cattle, which is their main active, as it is for anybody living in a village. Zaryl, wants to obtain a loan to buy cement and sand for building a jerry building and garage. In a very short time they are going to harvest the crops. They hope that they will be able to finish building before harvesting starts. 

Zaryl’s partners are: Venera, Gulzina and Orosulbu. Venera, 24, is married and has two little children. Together with her husband, she raises livestock. In addition, Venera sells milk to local villagers. Venera needs a loan to purchase goods for sale. She wants to open a small shop by her house where she would sell food items.

Gulzina, 63, and her husband have brought up four daughters. All of their daughters are married and live separately. She and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. This has been their main occupation for thirty years. Gulzina needs a loan to purchase coal for winter.

Orosulbu, 62, is mother to nine children. Except the youngest son, all of the other children have gotten married and live separately. Orosulbu prefers not to depend on her children and earns her livelihood by raising livestock and selling milk. Orosulbu needs a loan to buy a heifer for subsequent breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy cement and sand for building a jerry building and garage.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock rice and to buy and sell oil, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Savali

texts.en:
Savali T., a 35-year-old woman living in the town of Leusoalii, runs a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. She is married and has one small child. Savali has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 400 tala a month.

Savali joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 tala, which was used to expand the business, Savali is now requesting a loan of 2000 tala which will be used to renovate the business. This will be her fourth loan from SPBD. Savali plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating a general store

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Maria del Carmen tiene 59 años de edad, es casada con dos hijos mayores de edad, que ya están casados y con familias aparte. La señora Maria se dedica a la compra-venta de huevos y gallinas los cuales comercializa de forma ambulante en el mercado oriental de Managua. Ella dio inicio a este negocio hace ya 14 años, ayudándole a vender a su mama que era la que originalmente tenía el negocio. Después decidió independizarse, compro 300 cajillas de huevos y empezó a venderlas en Managua. Actualmente están presentando un problema de que el precio del huevo se ha mostrado muy inestable, haciendo que cada día las ganancias de ella sean menores que las que obtenían antes. Sin embargo, la señora se ayuda con la venta de gallinas, ya que obtiene un buen precio. El crédito será invertido en la compra de  más mercancía, que le permitirá hacer frente a la época navideña en que las ventas se incrementan. Su meta es llegar a comprar un vehículo para poder vender su producto de una manera más fácil, sin tener que andar pagando a los buses para que le lleven la mercadería.
texts.en:
Maria del Carmen, 59, is married and has two grown children. The children are married and have their own separate families. Maria buys and sells eggs and chickens. She is a street vendor in the Mercado Oriental of Managua. She started this business 14 years ago. She helped her mother, who originally had the business, sell. Later, she decided to become independent. She bought 300 cases of eggs and started to sell them in Managua. There is now a problem in that the price of eggs is very unstable. That means that each day her earnings are less than the day before. Nevertheless, she helps herself by selling chickens, and she gets a good price. The loan is to buy more merchandise, which will put her in front of the Christmas season as sales are increasing. Her goal is to buy a vehicle to be able to sell her product in an easier way without having to keep on paying the buses to carry her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo G., who is known in his community as “Danny,” is 38 years old and is married to Myrna. They are blessed with one son named Danny Boy G., seven years old. They live in Barangay Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. They aim to be successful in life to give their son a better future. Despite the hardships and difficulties in life, they strive harder to earn a living.

Farming is their way of making a living. They till their land twice a year to plant rice and vegetables. They are also engaged in hog raising to earn additional income. They want to expand their plantation to have a plentiful harvest and to improve their piggery by increasing their livestock. Since they don’t have enough capital, they want to borrow from Kiva lenders the amount of 10,000 Philippine pesos to be used in acquiring the needed materials for the maintenance of their crop production and piggery. They hope that through patience and sacrifice, they will achieve their goal. They believe that “God is merciful to those who are honest and faithful.”

loans.use: Additional capital for his hog raising business

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en: Ma. Fe O. lives in Masville Cubay, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She is 34 years old and married. Her husband has operated their watch-repair business for the past 29 years in the city proper of La Carlota. The couple is blessed with five children, ages 5 to 16 years old. Ma. Fe started from nothing. They live in a very dilapidated house because her husband's income cannot support the total needs of the family. She worried about the future and what would happen if her children started going to school. Thus, she invested in a pig-fattening business that can also help in defraying family expenses. She continued her business until such time that she could expand it. In 2004, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon for the said purpose of expanding the businesses, especially the pig-fattening business. She was able to improve her business by buying additional pigs for fattening. With one sow to raise, she has used some of her loan as additional capital for her watch-repair business. She was able to earn a minimum of 3,600 Philippine pesos per month. She saves most of her income for the education of her children. Ma. Fe joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so she could have her own business and to help her husband for her children's future because she wants all of them to finish their studies and get good jobs. Ma. Fe's previous loan of Php 15,000 was utilized for the pig-fattening business and was fully paid on time and in full without delay. With her 10th loan, she will use Php 18,000 as additional working capital for her business. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her pig-fattening business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria M. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 49 years old. Victoria is married and has children. To make a living, Victoria raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs to sell. Victoria has been engaged in her business for years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities. In 2009, Victoria joined ASKI, Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Victoria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Reynalyn's Group

texts.en:
Reynalyn M. is from the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 23 years old. Reynalyn is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Reynalyn is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Reynalyn owns & operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Reynalyn is just starting this business.

In 2009, Reynalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynalyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Reynalyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn Q. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 41 years old. Evelyn is single and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Carlos Javier

texts.es:
Carlos G. V. de 22 años de edad vive en casa de su padre junto con un hermano el cual tambien trabaja y aporta en los gastos de la casa ellos viven en Caserio Barrio Nuevo – Ocucaje.
El sr. Es soltero desde pequeño a trabajado como ayudante de panadería ya que su meta es surgir y ser mejor cada día èl es un joven con buenas rferencias de responsabilidad.
El sr. se dedica al transporte diario de 7.00am hasta las 9.00 pm realizando colectivo de Ica – Ocucaje ida y vuelta este trabajo lo realiza desde hace 3 años actualmente el carro donde trabaja es alquiler venta por eso que solicita le financiemos para poder terminar de cancelarlo y de esa manera tener algo propio.
Es una persona con bastante ganas de salir adelante es bien luchador y es considerado un buen hijo ya que apoya a su padre a pesar de que el sr tambien trabaja como abrero de campo.
texts.en:
Carlos G. V. is 22 years old and lives in his father’s house with his brother, who also works and contributes to the household expenses. They live in the village of Barrio Nuevo in Ocucaje. Carlos is single and worked as an assistant at a bakery when he was much younger. His goal at the time was to emerge as a better person each day. For a young man, he has good references and has demonstrated responsibility.

Every day, Carlos provides transportation services from 7am until 9pm for the local cooperative. He has been working the route between Ica and Ocucaje for the past three years. Carlos currently leases a car, so he is requesting a loan so that he can terminate his lease and acquire a vehicle of his own.

Carlos is a person who desires to get ahead. He is known for his fighting spirit and considered to be a dutiful son for supporting his father even though they both work in the same occupation.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Terminate the rental agreement of the car he is using so that he can purchase his own vehicle

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
Mrs. Marisa A. is 38 years old, married, and has two children. She lives in Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. Her husband is a tricycle driver and he supports their basic daily needs. Marisa sells her vegetables at the public market in Tambulig. From her vegetable-vending business she approximately earns 4,000 PHP a month.
Marisa successfully repaid her previous loan of 4,000 PHP from Kiva partner, PMPC. The purpose of that loan was to buy other kinds of vegetables to sell. As of now, she has a new loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC and that loan is intended for her business only. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her vegetable-vending business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth es una señora casada que tiene 3 hijos, vive en una casa que es prestada, la casa donde viven Elizabeth y sus hijos es de sus suegros, actualmente vive sola ya que su esposo se encuentra en España y hace todo esfuerzo para sacar adelante a su familia. 
Elizabeth se dedica a su actividad de elaboración de pan desde hace bastante tiempo, debido a que el negocio es pequeño quiere explorar nuevos nichos de mercado y se quiere diversificar comprando una máquina de coser para realizar otro tipo de mercaderías. Elizabeth no tiene mucha competencia al contrario quiere ampliar su mercado. El destino del crédito es para la compra de una maquina de costura. Las anteriores operaciones en Agrocapital las cancelo con puntualidad y responsabilidad teniendo buenos promedios en sus 2 anteriores créditos respectivamente.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman who has 3 children. She lives in a rented house. The house where Elizabeth and her children live belongs to her in-laws, but she is currently living alone since her husband is in Spain making every effort to support his family. Elizabeth has been making bread for quite some time. Since the business is small, she wants to explore new markets, and she wants to diversify by buying a sewing machine to make other types of merchandise. Elizabeth does not have much competition; on the contrary, she wants to expand her market. The purpose of this loan is for the purchase of a sewing machine. Her previous loans from Agrocapital were paid off punctually and responsibly.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment capital for new business

loans.name: Señoras De Taguan (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
Señoras de Taguan es un banco comunal formado por mujeres emprendedoras que luchan para salir adelante junto a sus familias, este banco está ubicado en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca  donde podemos disfrutar de la  belleza natural de la zona urbana y su cadena montañosa  que encierra laderas y mucha vegetación forjando un paisaje singular,  su gente se dedica a la agricultura,  ganadería y también a la elaboración de sombreros tejidos a mano.

Rosa tiene 40 años, se encuentra separada hace 7 años de su esposo ya que se fue ha trabajar en la costa Ecuatoriana y se hizo de otro compromiso, en su matrimonio concibió ocho hijos uno de ellos  es casado y vive de manera independiente, dos hijos trabajan en la ciudad  en el oficio de  albañil y es solo para sus gastos, otro de sus hijos no estudia pero le ayuda en casa, y los  otros cuatro aun son pequeños y estudian en la escuela de la comunidad.  Su vivienda es propia aunque pequeña y de adobe  pero eso les brinda seguridad. 

Ella  se dedica a la agricultura, cultiva  la tierra de quienes le dan trabajo ocasional, también cría animales  tiene una vaquita, un borrego y gallinas las que vende solo cuando tiene algún apuro económico. Se encuentra en su segundo ciclo trabajando con su banco comunal  con el dinero de su crédito va a comprar un chancho para criarlo, engordarlo y venderlo.

Su sueño es superarse cada día más, incrementar sus animales y arreglar poco a poco su casa.

La señora María C. vive en la comunidad de Taguan en el  cantón  Sigsig, tiene como atractivos el Castillo De Chobshi que se encuentra a solo 7 Km. de la cabecera cantonal de Sígsig al sureste del Azuay, éste es  un conjunto arquitectónico de tipo “kallanca” es decir de forma rectangular con gruesos muros de aproximadamente un metro y medio.

Nuestra socia tiene 56 años, se encuentra casada y es madre de ocho hijos de los cuales uno una hija se suicido dejando en la orfandad a dos  niños que ahora se  encuentran a su cargo y están estudiando en la escuela de la comunidad,  cinco de sus hijos  viven en la ciudad de Cuenca y los otros  salieron  de su comunidad en busca de mejores oportunidades y casi nunca le van a visitar, por ahora  vive sólo con su  hijo de 14 años que es  quien le ayuda en su hogar, sus dos nietos y  su esposo que  trabaja como albañil en centro de la ciudad y solo la visita el fin de semana, tienen  una casita pequeña que es de su propiedad.

María cría de animales como chanchos, gallinas, cuyes, ganado y solo los vende en sus apuros económicos, también se dedica a la agricultura siembra  hortalizas para luego viajar a  Cuenca y venderlas,  se encuentra en su segundo ciclo en su banco comunal, con el primer credito compró pollos que ya están listos para la venta y con el nuevo préstamo comprará unos chanchos para engordarlos y venderlos.  Su  sueño es de poder comprar más vacas para vender la producción de leche y elaborar quesos.
texts.en:
Señoras de Taguan is a community bank formed by enterprising women who work hard to make headway for their families. The group is located in the city of Cuenca, where they can enjoy the natural beauty of the city where the surrounding mountain range and plentiful vegetation forge a unique landscape. The locals make a living in agriculture, livestock and also making hand-woven sombreros. Rosa is 40 years old and has been separated from her husband for seven years, after he left to work on the Ecuadorian coast and found someone else. She had eight children from her marriage, one of whom is married and independent, two who work in the city at a construction office and help with expenses, one who is out of school but helps with the house, and the other four are still young and in school. She owns her home, which is small and made of adobe but still provides security. She makes a living in agricultural, cultivating the land and occasionally hiring workers. She also raises animal and has a cow, a sheep and chickens, which she sells only when she's in some economic trouble. This is her second loan cycle working with her community bank, and with the money she plans to purchase a pig to raise, fatten and sell. Her dream is to better herself more everyday, increase her number of livestock and fix her house up little by little. María C. lives in Taguan in the Sigsig area, which is located only 7 kilometers from Castillo De Chobshi, which is a popular architectural structure. She is 56 years old, married and has eight children. One of her daughters committed suicide, orphaning her two children, who are now under María's care and going to the community school. Five of María's children live in the city of Cuenca and the others left in search of better opportunities and almost never come to visit. For now, she only lives with her 14-year-old son, who helps around the house, her two grandchildren and her husband, who is a construction worker in the city center and only comes home on weekends. They have a small home that they own. María raises animals such as pigs, chickens, guinea pigs and cattle, and only sells them during times of economic trouble. She also makes a living harvesting vegetables and selling them in the city of Cuenca. This is her second loan cycle with the community bank, and with the first one she purchased chicken that are now ready to sell, and with the new loan she plans to purchase pigs to fatten and then sell. Her dream is to be able to have more cows so she can sell their milk and make cheeses.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase animals to raise and sell

loans.name: Hung

texts.en:
Hung D. L. is a 30-year-old man with a wife and two young children. Hung is a farmer. For the past five years, he has also been a carpenter. His monthly income is approximately 4,000,000 Vietnamese Dong (VND). He has participated in SEDA's micro-financing program since 2008 and has always met his repayment obligations on time. In his last loan, Hung borrowed 4,704,000 VND. 

Hung is now seeking 8,288,000 VND in order to purchase wood to make wooden household furnishings.

loans.use: To purchase wood to make wooden household furnishings

loans.name: Evelin

texts.es: Evelin de 37 años de edad es soltera, Helmut de 13 años es su unico hijo y esta estudiando el 6to grado de primaria. Evelin trabaja para la Alcaldia de Juigalpa desde hace 3 años como operador siscat de catastro.  Esta solicitando su 1er credito con el objetivo de obtener su propia vivienda, ya que actualmente no cuenta con una, sin embargo tiene su propio terreno y se inscribio en el proyecto colmena, quien le levantara su casita, pero necesita dar un aporte economico, aunque cuenta con una parte, pero le hace falta el financiamiento que solicita, y  espera contar con el apoyo de AFODENIC y Kiva para terminar este proyecto.  El mayor sueño que tiene es poder tener su casita y mejorarla en la medida que pueda ya que es el patrimonio que le dejara a su hijo.
texts.en:
Evelin is a 37 year old single mother to her only child Helmut, who is 13 years old and a sixth grade student. She has worked the past three years for the City of Juigalpa as a property tax surveyor. Evelin is requesting her first loan with hopes of acquiring her own home since she currently does not have one. However, she does have a plot of land on which to build. Evelin is enrolled in a housing program that will help her with the construction, but she needs to make a down payment in order for the work to begin. The problem is that she lacks the necessary funds. For this reason, she is depending on the support of AFODENIC and Kiva so that she can continue in the program.

Her greatest wish is to have her own house and make improvements to it so that one day she can leave it as an inheritance for her son.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Make the down payment required to begin the construction of her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pay AgroCapital and operating capital

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van T. is a 42-year-old married woman and mother. She has a rental shop inside the local market where she sells food and earns an adequate amount to help with her family’s financial problems. She has another financial earner in her husband who has the skill of making furniture by hand. This couple helps each other in order to generate money to support their four school-aged children. Van T. is taking out a loan to purchase more raw materials for her husband to produce sets of furniture to sell.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials.

loans.name: Dina Group

texts.es:
El grupo Dina lo integran tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es Cándida Rosa S. vende verduras y animales domésticos como gallinas, chancho, patos…etc. desde hace siete años aproximadamente. Ella con el crédito comprara yuca, papa, ayote, pipian y animales.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Jenifer H. quien vende cosméticos desde hace cinco años y Leonora H. venta de sandalias desde hace cuatro años. Ellas tienen la meta de aumentar sus negocios y crecer.
texts.en:
The Dina group consists of three hardworking women. One of them is Cándida Rosa S.; for about seven years, she has been selling vegetables as well as domestic animals such as chickens, pigs, ducks and so on. She plans to use the loan to purchase cassava, potatoes, squash, cushaw as well as animals. Her partners in the group are Jenifer H., who has been selling cosmetics for five years, and Leonora H., who has been selling sandals for four years. Their goal is to increase their sales volume and grow their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruits, vegetables, and domestic animals

loans.name: Jecelyn

texts.en:
Jecelyn R. is from the village of San Roque, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old. Jecelyn is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Jecelyn owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products,  and she also wants to invest some of the money in installing a mini-eatery in the local community. Jecelyn is just starting this business.

In 2008, Jecelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jecelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Jecelyn is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Jecelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: With God All Things Are Possible Group

texts.en:
M. S., is the leader of a group of five borrowers called With God All Things Are Possible. He is 34 years old, married and has three children who range from 5 to 12 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of financial support.  

For 13 years, he has been selling men's footwear such as sneakers, sandals, slippers, shoes, etc., in Redlight Market outside Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000-Liberian-Dollar portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollar group loan to buy more sneakers, sandals, slippers, shoes, etc. He describes himself as a very quiet person.

His dream is to improve his business and build a house. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sonnie M. is holding the sign in the middle of the group.

loans.use: To buy more sneakers, sandals, slippers, shoes, etc.

loans.name: Rosa Elena

texts.es:
Rosa de 64 años, hace 30 años atrás desde que inicio la cooperativa donde vive ubico el negocio de la tienda en su casa, ella vive en una zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución llamada “Primavera” de Duran. 

Ella tiene una tienda de víveres la mayor venta que tiene son los confites que vende y las bebidas, desde hace años ella ubico su tienda en la parte delantera de su casa, para mas seguridad le puso unas rejas (aparecen en la foto). Trabaja desde las 07h30 hasta las 22h00pm todos los días. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar confites y bebidas para su negocio, en el futuro quiere comprar un carro para transportar mejor la mercadería y así con los ingresos asegurar su vejez.
texts.en:
Rosa is 64 years old. Thirty years when the cooperative where she lives was established she set up a business in her home. She lives in a suburban area named Duran which is known for its ecology. She runs a greenhouse, selling plants on a wholesale basis. Rosa de 64 años, hace 30 años atrás desde que inicio la cooperativa donde vive ubico el negocio de la tienda en su casa, ella vive en una zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución llamada “Primavera” de Duran. She runs a convenience store. The greatest demand is for confections and soft drinks. For years the store has taken up the front part of her house, but for greater security she installed bars (as seen on the photo). She works from 7:30 in the morning until 10 at night, every day. With the loan she wishes to purchase confections and drinks to stock her business. In the future she wishes to purchase a car to be able to transport her merchandise with greater ease. She hopes to save a pension for her old age.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase confections and soft drinks.

loans.name: Adriana

texts.es:
la señora Adriana Z. es una persona muy dedicada a su negocio, su actividad es la venta de abarroteria, tiene varios años de realizar este trabajo.

Adriana es una persona muy responsable de sus actos, depende una persona de ella, de esa manera que tiene que trabajar muy fuerte para sacarlo adelante.
Varias personas comentaron que es bien responsable a sus compromisos.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia y asi surtir su negocio para tener mayores ganancias las cuales las necesita para cubrir con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Adriana Z. is a very dedicated to her business. She has had a general store for many years. Adriana is a very responsible person. She supports someone else so she needs to work hard to give him a better chance in life. Many people attest how responsible she is. She will use the loan to buy more inventory and diversify her business. That way she will have more income to cover her household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of juices, sodas, corn flour, "churros", tortillas, soap, toilet paper

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es: Rosario tiene la edad de 58 años, es casado y tiene 1 hijo de 21 años. En este momento Costa Rica esta sufriendo aguaceros que hace difícil la cosecha. Por eso él quiere comprar fertilizantes para la mejora de la cosecha de los cafetales para este año y ayudarle a las matas a producir más para el siguente. Rosario cuenta con su experiencia en café y su finca con lo cual tiene varios años. Desea de sea una finca productiva. Es el primer préstamo que ha recibido de FUDECOSUR y no ha realizados otros préstamos en bancos estatales. FUDECOSUR le brindó el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de interés es mucho más baja. Con los ganancias de su finca quiere invertir en el futuro de su finca y en el bienestar de su familia que es su mayor prioridad.
texts.en:
Rosario is 58 years old, married, and has a son who is 21 years old. At the moment, Costa Rica is experiencing heavy downpours which is making it difficult to harvest. He wants to buy fertilizers to improve his coffee fields this year and help his plants produce more in the following seasons. Rosario has experience growing coffee and has owned his farm for several years. He wants to have a productive farm.

This is the first loan he has received from FUDECOSUR and he has not received other loans from the state banks. FUDECOSUR provides this loan with greater convenience and a lower interest rate. His earnings will be reinvested in the future of his farm. The welfare of his family is his greatest priority.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers & supplies for his coffee crop

loans.name: Lidia Marina

texts.es: Lidia Marina se dedica a ofrecer el servicio de costura. Hace más de 11 años que tiene este negocio. Por lo que ha buscado la forma de mejorar sus ingresos, ella inicio con fondos propios pues ella siempre ha sido una mujer que le ha gustado sacar a sus hijos y proporcionarles todo lo necesario. Es por medio de su Mama que ella logro aprender este negocio y fuera un medio de vida para ella y su familia. Este crédito es para la compra de   materia prima como agujas, telas, hilos, tijera pues tiene pedidos que cumplir.
texts.en:
Lidia Marina is a seamstress. She has had her business for over 11 years. Seeking ways to improve her income, she used her own resources to start out because she’s always been a woman who wants to see her children get ahead and provide them with everything they need. She learned this craft from her mother and it became a way to support herself and her family. The loan is to buy raw materials like: needles, fabric, thread and scissors because she has pending orders to fill.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy needles, fabric, thread and scissors.

loans.name: Rovelyn

texts.en:
Rovelyn I. is from the village of San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 38 years old. Rovelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rovelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising ducks for sale. Rovelyn is just starting this business, and she wants to gain more income for her family.

In 2009, Rovelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Rovelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Rovelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Jovencia

texts.en:
Jovencia H. is from the village of San Luis, Gingoog City. She is 45 years old. Jovencia is widowed and has 13 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jovencia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap , toothpaste, canned goods & snacks in the local community. Jovencia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jovencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell and working capital. Jovencia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jovencia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the  business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

location.town: San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Mrs. Lang S. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Nat Chum, live on an island located 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1970 and have eight children: three sons and five daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home, one is a garment factory worker, one weaves silk at home, one assist his parents in the business and another one is in school.

Lang and her husband sell fruit (mangoes). They buy mangoes from their fellow villagers under contract. This means that they pay money before the harvesting season and then they collect mangoes to sell at Phnom Penh market. 

Lang has asked for a Kiva loan several times already. She hopes to continue increasing the number of mangoes she buys and sells, so she is applying for another loan of $500 to purchase mangoes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes under contract for resale.

loans.name: Ek

texts.en:
Ek Y., 39, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Angkor Wat temple. Y. raises pigs to sell, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is employed repairing temples, earning an income of about USD 6.17 per day. Y. has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 20 on other necessary expenses every month.

Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to grow more rice.

loans.name: You's Group

texts.en:
This loan group has four members. They have selected Mrs.You K. to be the group leader. They will use their portions of the group loan in different ways to support their families. The members live in Anlong Ta Sek Leu Village in Kandal Province. 

Mrs. You K. and her husband, Mr. Khut Sieng, are farmers who own a two-hectare (~ 5-acre) plot of land. They grow rice and sugar cane which they sell to support their family. Mrs. K. has a problem, because is time to grow rice in her field, but she does not have enough rice seed to grow. So, to improve production, Mrs. You K. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed.

She is 47 years old and the mother of three children. Two of her children are employed in a  garment factory and the other is an iron welder.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun S., 53, is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. S. is a housewife; she is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for its garment factory industry. The four children are all employed at the factory, earning an income of USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expenses. The family has to spend USD 70 on food, USD 15 on electricity, and USD 40 on other necessary expenses every month. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use.

loans.name: Dugar

texts.es:
Dugar V. V. tiene 47 años y vive en unión libre. El vive con su conviviente y sus hijas en el cantón de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar. 

Dugar es miembro de la ventanilla rural Unidos Somos Más. Esta nueva ventanilla hace parte de la comunidad Matilde Esther en la provincia de Guayas. Esta comunidad esta ubicada a 2 horas de la oficina de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar. El grupo cuenta con 23 socios y se dedican a diferentes actividades como agricultura, cría de ganados y pequeños restaurantes y comedores.   

Dugar se dedica a la producción de cacao y naranjas. El tiene este comercio desde hace 8 años. Dugar compra y vende sus productos en Bucay.  El solicita este crédito para mejorar el sembrio de cacao y naranjas. Através de este crédito el desea mejorar el futuro de su familia.

Su sueño es tener terrenos propios y una casa propia. El desafío que el enfrenta en su negocio es la baja producción en época de invierno.

En su tiempo libre, aparte de descansar, le gusta jugar indoor y volley y salir a las fiestas patronales.
texts.en: Dugar V. V. is 47 and in a common-law marriage. He lives with his partner and children in the Chillanes canton in the province of Bolivar. Dugar is a member of the Unidos Somos Mas ["United We Are More"] rural lending bank. This new bank is part of the Matilde Esther community in the Guayas province. This community is located 2 hours from the Chillanes office in the Bolivar province. The group has 23 members who have various businesses such as agriculture, the raising of livestock, and small restaurants and cafeterias. Dugar is a member of the Unidos Somos Mas rural bank. This new bank is part of the Matilda Esther community in the Guayas province. This community is located 2 hours from the Chillanes office in the Bolivar province. The group has 23 members who have different businesses such as agriculture, the raising of livestock, and small restaurants and cafeterias. Dugar produces cocoa and oranges. He has had this business for 8 years. Dugar buys and sells his products in Bucay. He is requesting this loan to improve his cocoa and orange crops. Through this loan, he hopes to improve his family's future. His dream is to have his own land and his own house. The challenge that he encounters in his business is the low production in the wintertime. In his free time, aside from resting, he enjoys playing indoor soccer and volley ball, and celebrating the holidays.

loans.use: to improve the cocoa and orange crop

loans.name: Amani

texts.en:
Amani is a 21-year-old woman from Sanour village, next to Jenin, in Palestine. Amani is a student. She took out a loan from FATEN to pay for last semester's tuition fees. Amani's father and brother will help her pay back the loan. Amani wants to find a job after graduation and have an independent source of income. Amani's brother is a NationA. Palestinian Authority employee.

Amani's brother, Hakam, appears in the picture here as she is a religious woman.

loans.use: To pay school tuition fees

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy essential materials for his work

loans.name: Digna Esperanza

texts.es:
La Señora. Digna L. es socia del banco comunal San Miguel, vive en la comunidad La Victoria Alta que pertenece a la parroquia del Valle, esta parroquia es admirada por la belleza natural que hay en el sector, su gente es muy trabajadora y se dedica al comercio, cría de animales y agricultura.

Doña Digna se dedica hace 3 años a la atención de un bar en una escuelita del sector, trabaja de lunes a viernes desde las 7 de la mañana hasta la 1 de la tarde, en su casa se dedica a la cría de animales como: pollos y cuyes.

La Señora. Digna tiene 39 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos de 20, 17 y 18 años de edad, su primera hija  estudia en la universidad, su segundo hijo en el colegio y su ultimo hijo en una escuelita del sector. Su esposo labora como albañil, viven en la casa que es de su hija.
 
Es socia del banco comunal hace 13 años, el dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más productos para el bar como: aguas, confites, gaseosas, bocadillos, etc. Su meta es crecer mucho más en su negocio y ayudar a que sus hijos se superen.
texts.en:
Digna L. is a member of the San Miguel community bank.  She lives in La Victoria Alta community which is located in El Valle parish.  This parish is admired for its natural beauty.  The locals are very hard working and work in commerce, raising animals and growing crops.

For three years, Digna has been serving in a snack bar in a local elementary school.  She works from Monday to Friday, from 7.00am to 1.00pm.  At home she raises animals such as chickens and guinea pigs.

Digna is 39 years old, married, and has 3 children aged 20, 17 and 18.  Her eldest child (a daughter) is studying at university, her middle child (a son) is in high school and her youngest (a son) attends a local elementary school.  Her husband is a construction worker.  They live in her daughter's home.

Digna has been a member of her community bank for 13 years.  She will invest her loan money in buying more products for the bar such as water, candy, soda, sandwiches, etc.  Her goal is to grow a lot more in her business and to help her children improve themselves.

loans.use: To buy water, candy, soda, sandwiches, etc.

loans.name: Kealy

texts.en:
Mrs. Kealy P. and her husband, Mr. Chamroeun Khen, have been married since 1977 and have eight children: five sons and three daughters. They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 15 kilometers away. 

Kealy is a rice farmer. When not at the farm, she also puts together fabric swatches for a clothing manufacturer (shown in the photo). Her husband is a primary school teacher.

She asked a Kiva loan once; she now is requesting another loan of $600 to make a handrail for her house.

loans.use: To make a handrail for her house

loans.name: Afiwa Mawulawoé Epse Degbe

texts.fr: Madame  Afiwa est mère d’un enfant.  Elle a 32 ans et est mariée. Elle habite quartier  Doumasséssé.  Pour contribuer au menage, elle fait la vente de produits de beauté, bijoux et mèches. Elle achète les produits au grand marché de Lomé et revend dans une boutique à  la devanture de sa maison.  Elle compte 5 ans déjà. Pour répondre a la demande sans cesse croissante, elle demande un crédit au près de Wages.
texts.en: Mrs. L. is a mother of one. She is 32 years old and married. She lives in the Doumasséssé quater. To help handle the household expenses, she sells beauty products, jewelry, and hair extensions. She buys these items at the Lomé Grand Market and sells them at a shop in front of her house. She has been doing this for five years. To respond to an ever increasing demand, she is requesting a loan through WAGES.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products, jewelry, and hair extensions

loans.name: Soro

texts.en:
A. Soro is married and her husband is Ahrorov Olimjon. She has two sons and a daughter. Soro is a very hardworking woman who trades in the «Korvon» market. She started her business with her own capital. She sells children's clothes. She has been in this business for 12 years. Soro wants to expand his business and get more profits for her families needs. Soro would like to get a loan of $2500 US for purchasing new seasonal children's clothes. She thanks all lenders who support her in realizing her desire. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy seasonal children's clothes

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina J., from the village of Sinama, is 58 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marcelina has been planting and harvesting corn for sale for over 28 years, earning approximately 20,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Marcelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to grow, she is now requesting her eighth loan of 50000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Marcelina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Monique

texts.en: Monique is 22 years old.  She has two children, ages 4 and 2 years; they are not yet in school. She owns a store in which she sells cooking oil, Irish potatoes, and kerosene. She has been running this business for 2 years. This helps her provide all the requirements of her family easily.  She is requesting a loan to buy more cooking oil and Irish potatoes in order to increase her profits.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil and Irish potatoes.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
Mavluda is married with 4 children. She sells kid's clothing at the central market and has been in this business for 8 years. Her extensive experience helps Mavluda to choose the right kind of inventory and make good sales. Mavluda enjoys selling clothing; moreover, this business brings her stable income. 

Mavluda would like to borrow 3,000 USD to purchase a summer collection of kid's clothing. She has used IMON International’s loans before and considers them to be very helpful for her business. 

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy new clothing to sell

loans.name: Yelian 1 Group

texts.fr: YELIAN 1 est un groupement constitué de onze personnes et dont la présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est nommée Cathérine. Les membres du groupe résident tous dans le même quartier au Bénin. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupement sollicite pour la première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Née en 1965 au Bénin, Cathérine vit depuis dix neuf ans dans une ville du Bénin avec sa famille. Cathérine est en effet mariée à un entrepreneur du nom de Romain et a quatre enfants, qui sont tous  scolarisés. Seulement, un des enfants reste à la charge de Cathérine et de son mari. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins de la famille. Cathérine n'a jamais été à l'école. Depuis environs dix huit ans, Cathérine vend des bambous à son domicile. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à contribuer aux dépenses familiales. Cathérine s'approvisionne dans une ville du Bénin. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Cathérine et à son groupe de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
YELIAN 1 is a group composed of eleven people whose president (the one with her hand raised in the photo) goes by the name of Cathérine. The group members all reside in the same district, in Benin. With the goal of increasing their working capital, this group is requesting a loan from ALIDé for the first time.

Born in 1965 in Benin, Cathérine has been living for nine years in a city in Benin with her family. She is actually married to an entrepreneur by the name of Romain, and she has four children, who are all educated. Only one of the children remains in their care. The couple jointly supports the needs of the family.

Cathérine never attended school. For about eighteen years, she has been selling bamboo out of her house. This business generates revenues for her that helps her to do her part to cover family expenses. She gets her supplies in a city in Benin. 

This initial loan will certainly enable her and her group to boost their level of business and to increase their customer base and their revenues.

loans.use: to buy bamboo

loans.name: Reforma 1-4 Group

texts.en:
Maria S. is one of the members of her group named La Reforma 1 to 4. This is a large group made up of twenty businesswomen and businessmen, dedicated to doing business all over their rural community, which is a batey (company town) between sugar cane fields outside San Pedro de Macoris. She has a long term partner and is a mother with seven children, all living with her in a simply structured home in a rural villa where many Haitian families live every day, working and fighting to have a better future. Maria S. is one of these women and men, doing business to improve her family's standard of living.

For about eight years, Maria S. has been operating her fried food stand and her comedor (a kind of local restaurant for lunch). She has improved her business with every loan she has taken with Esperanza. This is her 9th loan. She plans to use this loan to buy rice, meat, seasoning, vegetables, flour, cooking oil, etc.  Maria S. operates two food businesses. One is for breakfast and dinner (a fried food stall, where she sells chicken, meat, sausages, plantain, fried dough, etc), and the comedor, which is like a home restaurant where many people from the community come to have lunch.

She plans to continue to enjoy cooking and serving in her businesses. Another favorite thing to do is to be at her home with her family. Her story is generally representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. 

Note: There is more than one group picture in order to present as many visible faces as possible.

loans.use: to buy, rice, meat, seasoning, vegetables, flour, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: In this picture, Maame is seen with different types of soaps that she sells in Ankaful-fie, a village near Abura in Cape Coast.  She has been in the soap business for 3 years. Maame plans to use this loan to increase the quantity of soaps she acquires for sale. As part of her business plans, she hopes to reinvest the profit into the business. Maame is married to a farmer and together they live with their 6 children.

loans.use: to buy more soaps to increase her sales

loans.name: Bokk Liggey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Bokk Liggey est créé depuis le 14 mai 2010 jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois de Gabar; il est composé de dix huit femmes qui sont du même village et qui ont comme activités communes l'embouche et le maraîchage.

Madame Ndéye la responsable est mariée âgée de 45 ans, elle est mère de sept enfants; elle mène comme activité principale l'embouche ovine et fait en même temps du maraîchage, elle a une bonne expérience de plus de 15 ans dans ces secteurs. Sur la photo elle est debout tout à fait à droite couverte avec un châle orange.

Elle achéte ses moutons dans les marchés hebdomadaires et les engraisse pendant 3 à 4 mois avant d'écouler sa marchandise dans le marché hebdomadaire du village voisin.


Son prêt lui permettra d'acheter des béliers qu'elle souhaite revendre un mois avant le recouvrement pour ainsi rembourser son prêt.


Ses bénéfices obtenus lui servent à renforcer son épargne, pour les dépenses familiales c'est son mari qui s'en charge.
texts.en:
The Bokk Liggey community group was created on the 14th of May 2010, the day the Gabar village bank was opened. The group is made up of eighteen women who are all from the same village and all rear animals and crops for a living. Madame Ndéye is the team leader, and is 45 years old, married with seven children. Her main source of income is rearing sheep, which she does alongside market gardening. She has over fifteen years' experience in this field. In the photo, she is standing on the very right hand side, wearing an orange shawl. 
She purchases her sheep from the weekly markets and fattens them for 3 or 4 months, after which she sells them in the neighbouring village's weekly market. 
This loan will enable her to purchase rams which she hopes to re-sell a month before her loan deadline, so that she can repay it. The profits that she generates from her business activities will enable her to boost her savings- her family's needs are looked after by her husband.

loans.use: to purchase rams to rear then sell

loans.name: Jaime

texts.en:
Jaime is married with five children. Jaime is a farmer working in the Philippines and has been doing this work for 10 years. 

Jaime is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers and pesticides to use in his farming. Jaime hopes this loan will grow his operation. Jaime earned PHP 25,000 in his previous harvest last April. 

In the future, Jaime hopes to generate more income to make his family more economically stable.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Idrissa M

texts.en:
Idrissa is 42 years old and married with four children, ages between 7 and 15. He runs a Pharmacy in Grassfield, which is a neighborhood in Freetown. He also has three relatives he takes care of as well as their immediate family. 

Idrissa has owned this business for 5 years and sells blood tonic, capsules, and various types of medicines at his drugs store. He also earns income from renting out a house. He says that the main challenge to his business is fluctuation in prices.

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase various types of drugs. Idrissa says that the extra income from this loan will help him expand his house. In the future, he would like to be a supplier of drugs and expand his business more.

loans.use: to purchase various types of medicines such as malaria drugs and blood tonic.

loans.name: Dometilla

texts.en:
Dometilla, age 69, operates a piggery. She earns a living by selling live hogs to meat dealers. Sometimes they have the pigs slaughtered and sold at the market. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 4,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP)  in sales every week.

Dometilla and her husband Pascual live in Payatas, Quezon City, Philippines. Pascual assists her with the business. Together they work hard to provide a safe and secure future for their family.

To help her continue operations of her business, Dometilla is requesting a Php 12, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy feed and additional hogs. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Dometilla hopes that her business will continue to be successful. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy feed and additional hogs

loans.name: Prado Group

texts.en:
Monika, who is in her early 40s, is married with three children who go to school. She has had a grocery business for six years. She works from 6 am to 10 pm and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzanian, which she wants to use to buy more sodas, water, juice, chapatti and mandanzi.  Her dream is to one day be able to expand her business from two crates to four crates of sodas.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Prado", which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more sodas, water, juice, chapati and mandanzi.

loans.name: Lorenita

texts.en:
Lorenita is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. 

Lorenita has a food shop where she makes & sells viands like afritada & chicken pork adobo. She has had this business for six years. She requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy raw ingredients needed to make viands.

Lorenita has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Lorenita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients to make viands

loans.name: Twubahe Group

texts.fr:
Marie est une commerçante âgée de 26ans qui habite  la localité de Bukirasazi de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle  fait le commerce de détail dans sa boutique pour divers articles comme le savon, l’huile de palme, les biscuits, le sucre, le haricot, le riz, etc depuis 15ans. Elle  est aussi cultivatrice. Elle n’a  pas fréquenté l’école. Elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont 1qui étudie a l’école primaire.  
Le crédit Kiva  de 570,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité d’articles divers de boutique comme  le savon, l’huile de palme, les biscuits, le sucre, le haricot, le riz, etc à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  solidaire« TWUBAHE».
texts.en:
Marie is a 26-year-old trader who lives in the town of Bukirasazi, in Gitega province, in the center of Burundi. She is married with 3 children, one of whom goes to primary school. She herself has no formal education. She has been running her own store for 15 years and sells various products including soap, palm oil, biscuits, sugar, beans and rice. She also farms.

Marie will use the loan of 570 000 Burundese francs to restock her store with products to sell for a good profit. She is a member of the Twubahe solidarity group.

loans.use: to restock on products such as soap, palm oil, biscuits, sugar, beans, rice, etc.

loans.name: Martha Jeaneth

texts.es: Martha de 42 años de edad es casada, tiene 4 hijos de 16, 14, 12 y 10 años de edad.  Trabaja como comerciante en Santo Domingo.  Esta solicitando su 1er credito con el objetivo de mejorar su vivienda construyendo una pared que se encuentra en mal estado, pues teme que en cualquier momento ocurra un accidente.
