Con este préstamo comprará materiales para realizar su trabajo, en mayores cantidades, ya que durante la época navideña y de año nuevo tendrá mucho trabajo. 
Tiene dos hijos, pero vive solo con su hija menor y su marido, quien la apoya también económicamente. 
A Juana le ha sido muy grato participar de las reuniones de  Fondo Esperanza, junto a sus compañeros y a su asesora, ya que el ambiente es muy acogedor y solidario entre ellos. Juntos realizan actividades de apoyo para todos, como por ejemplo “canastas familiares” (alimentos no perecibles) y rifas entre otras cosas. También a Juana le ha servido mucho lo que aprendió durante una reunión sobre cómo organizar su dinero. 
Talcahuano es una comuna y ciudad-puerto de la región del Bíobío, al sur de Chile. Es conocida como uno de los principales puertos del país. Su nombre en mapudungun (lengua mapuche) significa "cielo tronador". Posee un paisaje natural  muy atractivo, debido a la combinación de ríos, mar, planicies fértiles, vegas y los cuerpos montañosos, con una hermosa vegetación. Su economía gira en torno a su puerto, su Base Naval, y un importante barrio industrial con empresas siderúrgicas, refinería de petróleo, petroquímica, cemento, gas, etc.
texts.en:
Juana is a member of the "El Esfuerzo" (The Effort) community bank which is located in the city of Talcahuano.  Juana has owned an established hairdressing salon in a main street of her city for 6 years.  She employs 3 people.  She will use this loan to buy larger quantities of supplies for carrying out her work since, during the Christmas and New Year periods, she will have a lot of work.

Juana has two children but she lives alone with her youngest daughter and her husband who also supports the family financially.  Juana is pleased to have participated in Fondo Esperanza's meetings together with her fellow group members and her advisor since the atmosphere is very welcoming and supportive.  Together the group's members carry out activities which support all members of the group such as, for example, preparing "family hampers" (non-perishable food) and raffles, etc.  Juana has also benefited a lot from what she has learned during the meetings, above all how to manage her money.

Talcahuano is a port city in Bíobío region, in the south of Chile.  It is known as one of the main ports in the country.  Its name in Mapudungun (Mapuche language) means 'thundering sky'.  It has a very beautiful natural landscape owing to the combination of rivers, sea, fertile plains, meadows and mountains which have a beautiful vegetation.  The city's economy revolves around its port, its naval base and an important industrial neighborhood with iron and steel companies, oil refineries, petrochemical, cement and gas companies, etc.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing supplies

loans.name: Mishi

texts.en:
Mishi is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is house rent.  She hopes to establish her own home in the future.

Mishi has been operating a retail shop business for the past three years, selling to her neighbors. Mishi faces a major challenge in the seasonality of demands in her business. During the holiday season, the demand for goods is higher than during the months of January to May,  when the demand is low. 

With the Kshs 80,000 loan, she wants to purchase 2 bags of sugar, beans, rice, 10 bags of charcoal, and a dairy cow. She decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation in the community.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, beans, rice, charcoal, and a dairy cow

loans.name: Sorm

texts.en:
Mr. Sorm S. is 29 years old. His wife, Mrs. Rotha Pach, is 26 years old (pictured together)--they live along National Road Number 1, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. They have been married since 2006 and have a young son. 

Sorm is a building contractor (laying brick and plastering the ceiling and walls of houses). His wife is a garment factory worker. He does not have enough work, so he is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase additional materials to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for his construction business

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys, a member of the Manantial (“Spring”) Village Bank, is 47 years old and married with three children; two are in college and one is still in high school. 

Gladys sells spices in the Nazarena Market in the city of Ayacucho. Business has been somewhat slow lately due to the unseasonable rain in Ayacucho. She has been a member of FINCA Peru for 10 years now and has learned a lot from the training they offer. She would like to expand her business, and also hopes that her children become professionals.

loans.use: To purchase spices to sell.

loans.name: Tha

texts.en:
Mrs. Tha S. (shown in the photo with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Samet Mon, have been married since 2000 and have two children, one son and one daughter. The family lives across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Tha is a silk weaver. Her husband is a wooden house builder and he is a chef as well. He cooks for weddings and other ceremonies in his village. Tha has asked for several Kiva loans, and she is now asking for another loan of $600 to purchase materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Lolango Plus Group

texts.en:
Julienne is the president of the Community Bank “Lolango Plus,” composed of 15 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through MFI HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Julienne runs a restaurant southwest of Kinshasa. She began her business in 1984. Her beginning capital was $90. With hard work and determination, her business has prospered. Julienne is now well known and liked in this area. She has already received five times the MFI HOPE DRC loans and fully repaid them. Since that time her business has prospered, and the loans she has received have helped her rent a well-located business place. She makes about $50 profit each week. Julienne intends with the next loan to increase the inventory of her restaurant to meet customer demand and generate additional profits. She is 57 years old and married. She is the mother of seven children between the ages of 20 and 35 years old. Today, one of them attends school. Her ambition is someday to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: to increase the inventory of her restaurant to meet customer demand and generate additional profits

loans.name: Tharcis

texts.en: Tharcis is 32 years old.  She has 4 children who are between the ages of 3 and 12.  Her husband sells goat meat and Tharcis sells goat hides.   She has been in this business for 7 years.   Tharcis is requesting a loan to buy more hides to make more profits.  With the profits, she plans to renovate her house.

loans.use: buy goat hides to sell

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida L. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 41 years old and widowed, with 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Nida runs a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Nida has been engaged in her business for more than 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

Nida joined HSPFI this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida is requesting her first loan, for 5000 PHP, to be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Selfa

texts.en:
Selfa, age 55, has been in the business of raising pigs for five years. She also helps her husband grow rice crops on their farm. They have a 20-year-old child. 
 
Selfa plans to use her loan to purchase pig feed and vitamins. In the future, Selfa hopes for her piggery to expand.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and vitamins

loans.name: John

texts.en: John, a 36-year-old married father of two, sells clothes to earn a living.  In business now for two years, he employs three people.  Previously without a business premise, through Faulu Kenya John was able to grow his business and establish one.  He hopes to further expand his enterprise and employ more people. John is requesting a loan of 60,000 Kes to buy more clothes and to renovate his house.

loans.use: to buy more clothes and to renovate his house.

loans.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina is a 47-year-old married woman living in Dodan, Peñablanca, Cagayan. Lucina has been in the business of hog raising for two years. She is also engaged in rice selling. She earns approximately PHP 5,000 monthly from her businesses. She is requesting a loan of PHP 4,000 to purchase hog feed and other supplies.

In the future, Lucina would like to make frequent sales and consistent profits to make her family more economically stable.

loans.use: to purchase hog feed and other supplies

loans.name: Maria Lucia

texts.en:
Maria Lucia, 42, is a member of a band called "Roland's Band" in Otavalo, Ecuador. She is seeking an individual loan, but is pictured with the other members of her band. Maria Lucia plans to use her loan to purchase an audio amplifier for her band's performances. 

She is married and has five children, aged 22, 20, 18, 13 and 11. She is a humble person who desires to overcome personal and socioeconomic obstacles. "Roland's Band" began as a hobby because Maria Lucia's son enjoyed music. Three of her sons are now members of the band. She reports that her business is going very well and that there is demand for "Roland's Band" to perform every weekend. Her dreams are for her band to record their music and continue moving forward with her children and husband. 

Maria Lucia reports that there is competition in her line of work, but she does not have a problem with that because she gets along well with her children and her husband and their musical business.

loans.use: to buy an audio amplifier for her band

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba is married and has 6 children. She makes soya kebab for sale in Abura (as shown in the picture). The kebab is made from soya beans. Her husband is a mason. Araba uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of their home. Araba will use this loan to puchase bags of soya beans to process into kebabs for sale. Her future plan for her business is to build a snack bar.

loans.use: buy soya beans to make kebabs for sale

loans.name: Noupagagnon V Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe NOUPAGAGNON V sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à  TAMBA, un des villages de la commune de NANTIEN dans la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Les spéculations cultivées sont : l’arachide et le pois sucré avec SOUCKO 1ère à droite position debout de la photo.
 Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et les semences pour entretenir : 0.5 hectare. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter au mieux son espace cultural pour en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The six members of the Noupagagnon V group are married women averaging 37 years of age with three children and living mostly in polygamous families in Tamba, a village in the commune of Nantien, Sikasso Prefecture, the third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better manage their agricultural activities during the rainy season.

They are on their fifth loan with the institution, and their prior loans have been duly repaid.

They cultivate peanuts [ground nuts] and sweet peas, which is, for example, what Soucko does (she is the first one standing on the right in the photo). With her loan, she plans to pay labor costs, buy agricultural inputs [fertilizers etc] and seeds in order to work a land plot of 0.5 ha [1.2 acres].

After harvesting, the produce is sold at the village and at the Sikasso market to a customer base composed of both men and women.

She plans to earn an average income of 40,500 West African Francs per agricultural season. This income will allow her to repay her loan and help her husband provide for everyday household expenses. She would like to continue  collaborating with Soro Yiriwaso in order to cultivate her land better and derive a bigger income from it.

loans.use: to pay for manual labor and buy seeds, fertilizers etc.

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie is a 52-year-old married woman who lives in Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She has one child.. She sells fruit salad in the local community to earn a living. She has been doing this for two years and earns a monthly income of PHP 5,000. 

Jessie has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 at GDMPC to purchase additional materials for her fruit salad making. She has been with GDMPC for one year. She looks forward to owning a stall for snack vending in the market and earning more income for living.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for fruit salad

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr:
Adjo   est une femme âgée de 39 ans. Elle est mariée à un plombier. Elle a trois enfants.
Adjo est couturière de formation mais travaille aussi comme revendeuse depuis 2001.Elle revend des pagnes et des produits de mercerie à Agodekè. Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé et mène cette activité toute seule.
Adjo a requis son troisième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des pagnes et des produits de mercerie.
texts.en:
Adjo is a 39-year old woman. She is married to a plumber. She has three children. Adjo is a seamstress by training but she also works as a vendor since 2001. She sells “pagnes” [traditional colorful fabrics] and sewing supplies in Agodekè. She stocks up in Lomé and works on her own.

Adjo has requested her third loan from WAGES in order to buy sets of “pagnes” fabric and sewing supplies.

loans.use: to buy sewing supplies and traditional fabrics

loans.name: Colonne De Feu Plus Group

texts.en:
Annie, from Kinshasa DRC, is the 46-year-old group leader of a 20-member group loan named “Colonne de Feu Plus” offered by MFI HOPE DRC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Annie, who is married, has five children between 16 and 25 years old. Three of her children attend school. Annie has been selling soya beans and miscellaneous since 1994 in the western part of Kinshasa. Currently, her business brings in a profit of US$60 per week. Annie plans to use the coming loan from Hope to increase her inventory by purchasing one more soya bean sack for reselling at profit in order to increase her income. Annie has a point of sale within her community. She dreams one day to open a large soya bean facility in her environment.

loans.use: to increase the inventory of her business by purchasing one more soya bean sack for reselling at a profit.

loans.name: Bernadelte

texts.en:
Bernadelte is 25 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  She is single and has 2 children.  One of her children is currently in school.  Bernadelte has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for 3 years. She also sells shoes as her second business.        

To help expand her business, she has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Bernadelte hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, she hopes to expand her business.    Bernadelte is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en:
Chheang and her husband, Kheng, are farmers. They grow rice and vegetables on their farmland in the village where they live. Chheang is asking for a loan of $700 to help with her rice and vegetable farm by purchasing seed, fertilizer and pesticide.

The couple has been married since 2002 and has two young sons. They are living in a village along National Road Number 6, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Photo: Chheang is at home with her young son, not at the farm.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet  lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children who all go to school. She is a tailor. She operates her business on a retail basis in a rented shop. She has been in business for the last 6 years. Annet works six days a week. 

She has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy a Baby Lock sewing machine and rolls of clothing material.  Her major challenge is seasonality and defaulters. Her goal is to expand into a fashion and design shop. She lives in her own house, and her family has access to piped water and electricity. Her monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy a Baby Lock sewing machine and rolls of clothing materials

loans.name: Mercedes Dolores

texts.es:
La Señora. Dolores es socia del banco comunal Libertad en Progreso, vive por una comunidad que pertenece a la parroquia Victoria del Portete (Cuenca), este lugar es de clima frió y propicio para la cría de ganado por sus amplias llanuras, su gente es muy amable, cálida y mantienen la cultura y tradiciones de sus pueblos.

La Señora. Dolores tiene 45 años, es casada en su unión conyugal ha concebido 7 hijos, 2 de sus hijas son casadas e independientes, 3 trabajan y le ayudan económicamente, y sus dos últimos hijos estudian en una escuelita de la localidad. Su esposo es de profesión sastre y tiene un pequeño taller, la casa en la que viven es de su propiedad.

Doña Dolores se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar, cuida de su familia y cómo pasa el mayor parte del tiempo en casa se dedica a la cría de animales como: cuyes, gallinas, borregos y vacas, vende sus animales en su comunidad o en la ciudad cuando tiene alguna necesidad económica.

En el banco comunal se encuentra en su cuarto crédito y su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en telas para el negocio de su esposo y también en el alimento para sus animales.
 
Su meta es construir una casa para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Dolores is a member of the “Libertad en Progreso” communal bank.  She lives in a community belonging to Victoria del Portete (Cuenca) Parish.  This is a cold climate place apt for raising livestock on its wide plains.  Its residents are kind, warm and keep the customs and traditions of their peoples.

Dolores is 45 years old, married and has 7 children.  Two of her daughters are married and independent, three work and help out economically.  Her two youngest children go to the local elementary school.  Her husband’s a tailor by profession and has a small workshop.  They own the house they live in.

Dolores does the household chores, takes care of her family but since she spends most of the time at home she also raises animals like guinea pigs, chickens, sheep and cows that she sells in her community or in the city when an economic need arises.

She’s in her fourth loan with the communal bank and will use this new loan to buy fabric for her husband’s business and also feed for her animals.  Her goal is to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to buy fabric and animal feed.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
La señora Julia tiene 47años D. edad, está casada con el señor Andrés quien tiene 54 años, ambos oriundos D. la ciudad D. Tobatí, tienen 3 hijos, la edad D. ellos son  25, 19 y 10.  
Julia se dedica a la venta D.  Bebidas D. todo tipo, como ser cervezas, gaseosas, vinos y otros, tiene su local D. ventas en su domicilio y al costado una cancha D. voleibol. Ella es muy conocida en el barrio por su buena atención y cordialidad. Comenta que su local le genera muy buenos ingresos, en especial los fines D. semana que es cuando mas clientes tiene, por ello desea seguir invirtiendo en su negocio, por lo que solicita el crédito, para la compra D. bebidas, como ser cervezas, whiskys y demás para abastecer su negocio y satisfacer la demanda D. sus clientes.
texts.en:
Sra. Julia is 47 years old and married to Sr. Andrés, age 54. Both of them are natives of the city of Tobatí. They have three children (ages 25, 19, and 10).

Julia sells beverages of all types such as beer, sodas, wines, and other products. She has a store in her home, which is next to a volleyball court. Julia is well-known in her neighborhood for providing good service and her friendliness. She says that her store generates a good income, especially on the weekends when most of her customers visit. For this reason, she wants to continue investing her business.

The loan she requested will be used to buy beverages such as beer, whiskey, and other products so that she can restock her business and satisfy the demands of her customers.

loans.use: to buy beer, whiskey, wine, and other beverages.

loans.name: Gandaria 1 Group

texts.en:
Rohayati is 44 years old and married with three children.  For the past three years, she has been selling kitchen equipment  from her bicycle around her neighborhood.  Her business has been doing well and the income helps send her children to school. She will use this loan to buy more equipment such as frying pans, cooking spoons, and graters to resell to her customers.  

She hopes that someday she will have enough money to buy a stall for her business so she does not have to travel by bicycle.  She also hopes that her children will be able to stay in school and get a good education because she only completed elementary school.

loans.use: to pay for frying pans, cooking spoons, graters and other kitchen tools to resell.

loans.name: La Union Es Progreso - Cajas Group

texts.es:
La Señora NICOLASA, tiene 55 años D. edad, casada, tienes 03 hijos menores D. edad, mujer muy trabajadora con entusiasmo. Es integrante D. la Alcancía Comunal "LA UNION ES PROGRESO- CAJAS”.   

Ella tiene una bodega alquilada que venD. bebidas, azúcar, arroz, aceites, verduras, etc.
El préstamo solicitó para abastecer con más productos e implementar su bodega, En el futuro desea comprarse su terreno y construir su casa.

Se esfuerza mucho para que pueda dar una buena calidad D. vida a su hijo. La socia  viste con chompa color plomo y sobrero está ubicado lado izquierda,  a lado D. la socia que viste D. polo color rojo.
texts.en:
Nicolasa is 55 years old and married with three children under the age of eighteen. She is a hard-working, enthusiastic woman, and is a member of the Communal  Bank “La Unión es Progreso – Cajas” [Unity is Progress – Banks].

She has a grocery store that she rents where she sells drinks, sugar, rice, oils, vegetables, etc. She is requesting the loan to be able to stock and supply her store with more products. In the future, she hopes to purchase a plot of land and build a home.

She works hard to be able to proviD. a good quality of life to her children. She is wearing a grey sweater and hat, and is on the left siD. of the photo, next to the member wearing the red shirt.

loans.use: Grocery store - sale of food products.

loans.name: Sinat

texts.en:
Sinat is a garment worker. Her husband, Ban, is a construction worker. They have been married for seven years and have no children. 

Sinat is living with her parents in a village about seventeen kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. She now wants to live separately by building her own house, but she does not have the money to do so. Therefore, she is requesting her first loan in the amount of $1,000. 

Photo: Sinat is pictured at her parents’ house.

loans.use: to build her own house.

loans.name: Karina Elizabeth

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Esperanza y Progreso se reúne cada quince días en la ciudad de Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a Karina, tiene 26 años de edad está soltera y vive en la casa de los padres, ella tiene una niña de 7 años que es de una prima que falleció y la quiere como que si fuera de ella y estudia en escuela.

Ella es una joven muy trabajadora pues  para ganarse la vida y para que a su niña no le falte nada trabaja en una fábrica en la ciudad de Manta. Con este crédito ella quiere empezar un negocio de venta de zapatillas, quiere empezar en esta época ya que se viene la época de Navidad y Año Nuevo y las ventas son muy buenas en esta temporada, ya tiene varios encargos que le han hecho sus amistades y conocidos.

Este crédito lo va  a emplear para ir a Guayaquil y comprar zapatillas para la venta. Es su tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que les da la institución. 

Sus sueños son seguir adelante en su negocio y en su vida personal.
texts.en:
The Esperanza y Progreso (Hope and Progress) communal bank meets every two weeks in the city of Montecristi, known for its rich culture and pre-colonial art known nationally and internationally.  It’s also known for its famous straw hats.

Here we meet 26 year old Karina.  She’s single and lives with her parents and takes care of her seven year old niece since her mother passed away.  She loves her as if she were her own daughter.  She attends school.

She’s a very hardworking young lady who earns her own living so that her little girl wants for nothing.  She works in a factory in Manta and will use the money from this loan to start a shoe business.  She wants to begin this season, now that the Christmas and New Year season is approaching and sales are good during this season.  She already has some orders from friends and acquaintances.

She will use the money from this loan to travel to Guayaquil to buy shoes to sell.  This is her third cycle in the communal bank and she likes it because of the help she gets from the institution.

Her dream is to continue moving forward with her business and personal life.

loans.use: to buy shoes for sale

loans.name: Kurban

texts.en:
Kurban, from the village of Kasumlo, East Georgia, is 63 years old and lives with his wife, Sanabar, and his 28-year-old son. The family has a small dairy farm, their main source of income, and Kurban and Sanibar sell milk in the village. They also have a greenhouse where they grow vegetables which Kurban sells to local retailers. Total average monthly income of the family is 1000 Laris.

Kurban is requesting this loan to purchase a milk cow. With the resulting increased income, Kurban and Sanabar will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow for expansion of the dairy farm.

loans.name: Raquel Adriana

texts.es:
La Señora. Raquel es socia del banco comunal Yanuncay, vive por la ciudad de Cuenca, ciudad que gracias a la belleza de su Centro Histórico y su Cultura fue nombrada Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad en diciembre de 1999, cuenta con una gran variedad en la gastronomía, su gente es amable y gentil. 

La Señora Raquel tiene 26 años, es casada y en su unión conyugal ha concebido 2 hijos  de 7 y 3 años de edad, su primer hijo estudia en una escuelita de la ciudad. Su esposo es comerciante, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en casa de familiares.
 
Doña Raquel es de profesión Ing. En Contabilidad y lleva la contabilidad del negocio de  su papá, también se dedica a la venta de ropa.
 
Se encuentra reingresando al banco comunal y su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de víveres para su hogar.
 
Su meta es seguir un postgrado de su profeción.
texts.en:
Raquel is a member of Yanuncay Communal Bank.  She lives in the city of Cuenca, which, thanks to the beauty of its historic center and its culture, was named a World Heritage Site in December 1999.  The city has a broad variety of gastronomy and the people there are pleasant and kind.

Raquel, 26, is married and has two children from this relationship, ages 7 and 3.  Her first child studies in elementary school in the city.  Her husband is a shopkeeper.  They do not have their own house so they live in the house of family members.

Raquel is an accountant by profession and does the accounting for her father's business.  She also sells clothing.

She is rejoining the communal bank and will invest her loan in buying supplies for her home.

Her goal is to  do graduate work in her profession.

loans.use: to buy supplies.

loans.name: Nonvignon Group

texts.fr: NONVIGNON est un groupe composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même groupe de tontine. Afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité, ce groupe sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Pauline Djessougbé (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 43 ans. Pauline Djessougbé a arrêté l'école au niveau primaire. Pauline Djessougbé est mariée à un revendeur du nom de François. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains scolarisés et deux à leur charge. Pauline Djessougbé vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Les diverses charges du ménage sont supportées par le couple. Pour cette raison, Pauline Djessougbé vend des produits des boissons, des condiments et des céréales dans sa boutiques depuis quinze ans. Pauline Djessougbé s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu, Pauline Djessougbé sollicite ensemble avec les membres du groupe NONVIGNON, un crédit auprès de ALIDé.

loans.use: Acheter des boissons.

loans.name: Las Piñas Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad caracterizada por el cultivo de nopales ya que gran parte de la población se dedica  al cultivo de esta verdura, desde que se va llegando a la comunidad se ven loa sembradíos enormes de nopales que existe en la comunidad además de que se les da muy bien el cultivó de nopales .  También cada uno de ellos tiene un negocio independiente ya sea ambulante o estable, son personas muy trabajadoras alegres cuando se trata de tener fiesta se organizan para que todo salga muy bien.
Doña Esperanza es una mujer trabajadora, responsable está muy contenta ya agradecida con el préstamo que le ofrece la institución porque será de gran ayuda ella tiene 49 años de edad está casada desde hace32 años con el señor Gregorio quien trabaja en la construcción de casas  juntos han formado una familia con 8 hijos de los cuales ya solo dos son dependientes  una que se encuentra estudiando su educación secundaria.
Don Gregorio y Doña Esperanza todos los domingos sales desde muy temprano de casa para trasladarse a la otro municipio para poder vender verdura y nopales, platica que el negocio lo iniciaron porque cierto día Doña Esperanza sembrar un solo algunas plantas para el alimento de su familia pero al ver que se daba muy bien decidieron iniciar con la venta de nopales pero también se les ocurrió que vender verdura sería una muy buena idea.
Llevan 12 años en el negocio por lo que le va muy bien para ellos son meses muy buenos ya que en todos los lugares las heladas perjudica la verdura y es cuando puedo pueden elevar un poquito el precio de sus verduras, ellos deben de llegar muy temprano al lugar para esperar su proveedor quien les vende la verdura, Doña Esperanza recordó que al inicio de su negocio su dificultad era el lugar ella no tenía espacio seguro para vender durante 5 años batallo con esta situación pero ahora ya tiene un lugar seguro aunque tuvo que para por el permiso pero así ya es más seguro.
 Ahora con aun préstamo comprara hule para tapar su invernadero ya que igual el nopal debe ser cubierto para que no le afecte el hielo, “Realmente el préstamo será de gran ayuda porque el hules es muy caro y para reunir cierta cantidad es algo complicado” comento Doña Esperanza.
En su negocio no tiene ninguna dificultad, aunque su sueño es poder logar tener más plantas de nopales, solo tiene tres mil plantas pero desea tener más para obtener más ganancias y asi segur mejorando su vivienda seguir apoyando a su hija en sus estudios.
Las integrantes del grupo son  Santasita quien invertirá en bolsas y cerillos María Guadalupe, Brenda Iveth, Araceli y josefina en fantasía, Dolores y Gricelda en nopales.
*La fotografía fue tomada en la casa de Doña Esperanza junto a unos nopales que tiene en casa, Ella es quien tiene la blusa negra*

loans.use: Comprara hule para los nopales.

loans.name: Kokou

texts.en:
Kokou J. was born in Tsévié in 1960. Coming from a humble family, he had to quit school in the 9th grade due to a lack of support. He had to go abroad to work. There, he was a cook in a restaurant up until he turned to his native land. With his savings, he started his own shop in 1990 selling items such as white rice, oil, cookies, drinks, and so forth. Then, to bolster his business, he made use of a $550 loan, which he repaid without a problem. An efficient man, he has complete mastery of his business. He is both honest and energetic, and he is married to a hairdresser. They have two children in middle school. Kokou’s business could be better developed if he had more loan capital, for he manages money well.

The loan of $1,200 that Mr. J. is currently requesting will serve as capital to stock up on sacks of corn and beans, mineral water, and various other items. It will also serve to open another sales outlet. Thus, he will be able to increase his business and augment his income in order to improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur J. Kokou est né à Tsévié en 1960. Issu d’une famille modeste, il n’a pu terminer ses études de troisième degré par manque de support. Il a dû partir pour l’étranger où il avait servi comme cuisinier dans un restaurant jusqu’à son retour sur la terre natale. Avec son économie, il a initié en 1990 sa propre boutique de vente de produits comme le riz blanc, l’huile, biscuits, boissons et autres, avant de bénéficier d’un crédit de $550 pour renforcer son activité, lequel crédit qu’il a bien gérer et rembourser sans incident. Il a une parfaite maîtrise de ses activités qu’il gère avec efficacité. Honnête et dynamique, il est marié à une coiffeuse avec qui il a eu deux (02) enfants qui font les études secondaires. Les activités de Kokou pourrait mieux se développer s’il avait bénéficié de fonds de crédit plus consistant car il en a une bonne maîtrise.

Ce crédit de $1200 que Monsieur J. Kokou sollicite aujourd’hui, servira à approvisionner sa boutique de sacs de maïs, de haricot, d’eau minérale et de divers autres produits et à ouvrir un autre point de vente. Ainsi donc, il pourra accroître ses activités et augmenter ses revenus qui serviront à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: To stock his shop with basic food items and to open another sales outlet.

loans.name: Sadiah

texts.en: S. is 55 years old. She prepares and sells coconut milk rice and some crackers. She lives by herself since all her children are married and live separately. Sometimes she sells fish as well. She is a member of MBK and wants to have a $50 loan to increase her business by selling fish. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Preparing and selling coconut milk rice and selling fish

loans.name: Kankovi

texts.en:
Born in Aklakou in 1959, Mrs A. Kankovi is married and the mother of three children. Her husband is a taxi driver. She was forced to leave school at a very early age because of a lack of support and is now starting to produce and sell cakes. To do this she is using the funds earned from selling chilled water, something she did previously. Her production capacity in the beginning was limited to a few bowls of flour and two litres of vegetable oil. She is seeing the demand for her cakes increase and wants to expand her business by buying bags of wheat flour, drums of vegetable oil and firewood. To do this she is asking for a loan of $700 to increase her production and revenue, thus improving the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Née à Aklakou en 1959, Madame A. Kankovi est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Son mari est conducteur de taxi. Ayant abandonné très tôt ses études par manque de soutien, elle commença à produire et à vendre des gâteaux grâce aux revenus qu’elle a tiré de la vente de l’eau fraîche, activité qu’elle menait auparavant. Sa capacité de production au départ était limitée à quelques bols de farine et à deux litres d’huile végétale. Ayant constaté que la demande augmente, elle désire agrandir son activité : acheter des sacs de farines de blé, des bidons d’huile végétale, des bois de chauffe. Pour cela, elle sollicite ce crédit de $700 pour augmenter sa production et tirer plus de revenu. Ainsi elle pourra alors améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: Production and sale of cakes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in additional merchandise

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha Beltran Blanco lives with her husband who has a pizza business. They have two children. She is part of the association 18 of September de Villa Tejada, in the city of El Alto. Her main activity is the sales of spare parts for domestic appliances, in Uyustus in the city of La Paz. 8 years ago, Martha bought spare parts from wholesalers, primarily those that come from Peru and for all types of brands. She will use the capital to increase her merchandise, as well as make it more varied. This is right after the urgent need to generate more resources that enable her to make her rent on her stall, and to be able to sustain her home.

Martha B. Blanco, vive con su pareja que se dedica a la Pizzería, y es madre de dos hijos, pertenece a la asociación 18 de septiembre de Villa Tejada en la ciudad de El Alto. Su principal actividad es la venta de repuestos para electrodomésticos en la Uyustus, de la ciudad de La Paz, hace 8 años en el rubro, Martha compra los repuestos de vendedores mayoristas, principalmente aquellos que provienen del Perú y para todo tipo de marcas. Martha precisa de capital, para poder incrementar su mercadería, además de hacerla más variada, esto a raíz de la imperiosa necesidad de generar mayores recursos que le permitan cumplir con el alquiler de su puesto, y principalmente de poder llevar el sustento a su hogar.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise, cover the costs of the business and the household.

loans.name: Etruda

texts.en: Etruda is 32-year-old mother of three. She lives in the Buguruni area of Dar Es Salaam city. She has been in business for the past six years, running  a small pharmacy in the Buguruni area. She now wants to expand her pharmacy and is asking for $375.

loans.use: To expand her pharmacy business

loans.name: Nikita

texts.en: Mrs. Nikita M., 25, lives in Tarankhel, Thecho (Nepal). Thecho is a village that lies within the Lalitpur district. Most of the people here are engaged in agriculture. Mrs. M. has  four members in her family including herself. Her husband, Har Kaji M., is 27. Mrs. M. has  two sons. Her elder son is 14 and is studying in class 6 whereas her younger son is 10 and is studying in class 2. Goat farming is the only profession that Mr. and Mrs. M. have so they rely on it to support their family.. They need a loan of US$ 175 in order to buy  corn flour and other feed for their goats.

loans.use: To buy feed for her goats

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Mrs. Rose O. sells foodstuff and drinks. She is married with three children and she is 50 years old. She is from Edo State. According to her, if given the loan of $450, it will enable her buy more foodstuffs and drinks for sale. She learned the business for 6 months and started hers in 1998.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and foodstuff for sale

loans.name: Igembe B Group

texts.en:
Sophia S., age 54, is married and has 4 children (ages 34, 32, 28, and 24). For almost a year now, she has been running a business in the sale of whole and retail vouchers. Sophia's business is open from 7:30 am to 6 pm daily, and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about US$85.3.

Sophia now hopes to receive a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group members who have businesses in the sale of timber, poultry, and games products, and in running a saloon.

In the picture, Sophia is the second one from the left.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a 28 year old married woman with 2 children, ages 9 and 4. She and her husband also take care of one other child, age 4. Rehema owns a small cafe and pool table, a business she started in 2007. Every day she works from 7 A.M. to 9.30 P.M. at her business where she earns a monthly profit of about $240.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Iris Rocio

texts.es:
Mrs Iris is a member of the Carmen Cabrejos Community Bank, located at Jr. Cahuide No. 410, Calleria District, Ucayali State. She is 35 years old, married, and has two children. Her husband is a soldier. Iris invested the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos (Kiva Field Partner) of approximately $110 in a business buying and selling merchandise. At present, she works for herself buying and selling merchandise. She gets up at 7 am to prepare breakfast for her husband and children and afterwards she is busy selling her merchandise until 6 pm.

With this loan, which will be repaid in 5 months, Iris plans to buy clothing for men, women, and children, rings, bracelets, earrings, etc. to sell to her customers.

Iris is very happy that thanks to her effort, she has less worry, can help her children with their homework, and is able to make a contribution to her family. She is very grateful for the support that Manuela Ramos provides for her business.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Iris pertenece al Banco Comunal Carmen Cabrejos, ubicado en el Jr. Cahuide No 410, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 35 años y es madre de 2 hijos, su esposo es militar. Iris con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en un negocio de compra y venta de mercadería. En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio de compra y venta de mercadería, se levanta a las 7 am para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos y de su esposo y de allí se dedica a la venta de su mercadería hasta las 6 pm. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará: ropas para damas caballeros y niños, sortijas, pulseras, aretes, etc. Iris esta muy alegre, por que gracias a su esfuerzo puede estar mas tranquila, puede poyar a sus hijos en sus estudio y también puede aportar en su hogar,esta muy agradecida con el apoyo que le da Manuela Ramos para su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of more stock for retail sales

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian A. is married with a child. She is 34 years old and hails from Edo state, Nigeria. She sells clothes, body creams, shoes, and bags. She has been in business since 2004. She needs a loan of $350 to buy mother care products to sell.

loans.use: To buy mother care products for sale

loans.name: Ana Simone Fiso's Group

texts.en:
This group includes nine women from Vaitoomuli. They are honest women who work hard to start up their businesses. Some of them farm, some of them fish, and others sell vegetables in the village and at a larger market. They earn more than $100 tala (US $41) in profit every week. They are looking for their next loan to expand the businesses and for home improvement. They are aware of SPBD rules and regulations and they are strict in enforcing them in their group.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To  purchase farming and fishing equipment and supplies.

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.es:
Cristina started her business because she needed more income. Her husband was not able to give her money regularly because he was in the United States and out of work. She is not able to have a regular job because there is nobody to help care for her children. She began about 6 years ago after taking a course in custom sewing. She decided to buy a sewing machine, first to make clothing for her children. Her neighbors began to bring her mending jobs, and now she also makes complete garments for neighbors, friends, and some clients who have been coming.

She needs a loan of US$200, which she will repay in 4 months, to buy fabrics, threads, buttons etc. so she can create and sell children's outfits. With your help Cristina will get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Cristina inició el negocio porque queria tener otro ingreso ya que su esposo no le manda dinero en forma continua por que le falta trabajo, ya que su esposo esta en Estados Unidos y ella no puede tener un trabajo de planta por que no cuenta con alguien que le ayude a cuidar susu hijos Comenzó hace aproximadamente 6 años ya que ella habia tomado un curso de costura le gusto y decidio comprar una maquina de coser, primero minimo para hacer ropa para sus niños le funciono y los vecinos empezaron a llevarle composturas, ahora ya elabora prendas completas para los vecionos familiares y algunos clientes que han estado llegando.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $200 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar telas, hilos, botones, etc ya que realiza trajecitos de niños y los vende. Con tu ayuda Cristina saldra adelante.

loans.use: To buy work materials

loans.name: Moustapha

texts.fr:
Mr. MBEMGUE has a store located at the port of Ziguinchor, where he sells sports equipment. He is asking for a loan to strengthen his business. This is because during the wintering period, it is a business that works extremely well.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

M. MBEMGUE a un magasin situe au port de Ziguinchor, il y vend des equipements de sport. Pour renforcer son activite, il demande un credit. Car en cette periode d'hivernage c'est une activite qui marche fort.

loans.use: Sale of sports equipment

loans.name: Issaka

texts.fr: Issaka M. est âgé de 33 ans, marié et père de 2 enfants. Il est revendeur d’huile à moteur à Kpalimé, une ville située à environ 120 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Issaka espère avec ce crédit acheter beaucoup plus de marchandises pour la revente afin de mieux répondre à la demande de ses clients et de gagner aussi plus d’argent pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille
texts.en:
Issaka M. is 33 years old, married and the father of two (2) children. He is a reseller of motor oil in Kpalime, a town situated about 120 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital. With his loan Issaka plans to buy much more merchandise for resale so that he can meet the demands of his customers. Also, he will earn more profit to support the needs of his family.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase containers of motor oil for resale.

loans.name: Musa Gwichara Tijikomboe Kichemchem Group

texts.en:
Musa G., age 31, is married with two sons (ages 5 and 3). He has a general store which he started 4 years ago. He works from 6am to 9pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $78.

In the past, Musa has taken out five loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase the stock of his general store. He now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. Musa will share this loan with his group, Tujikomboe Kichemchem, which has 15 members. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture Musa is the only man, standing second from the right in the back row.

loans.use: To increase stock of general store.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 49 years old and married with 4 children. Esther sells drinks and provisions in her shop. Esther is thankful to LAPO MICROFINANCE for linking her to Kiva lenders. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to stock her shop, so that she can sell in large quantities to her customers. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions to re-sell

loans.name: Idalia Noemí

texts.es:
La señora Idalia F. es originaria del municipio de Chichigalpa en la ciudad de Chinandega donde se desempeña en su negocio de servicio de molino siendo visitada por varios clientes que llegan a moler maíz, cacao, entre otros.

El servicio de molino es atendido todos los días por la señora F. desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana hasta el atardecer. Es importante destacar de igual manera que ella es una dama muy esforzada y comprometida con el bienestar de su hijo debido a que es madre soltera y debe mantener los estudios del pequeño y también suplir las necesidades del hogar. Con el crédito que espera en Ceprodel logrará comprar herramientas para la maquinaria de molinos para brindar un mejora servicio.
texts.en:
Idalia F. is from the Chichigalpa district in the city of Chinandega where she works in the mill business. Various clients visit her that arrive to mill corn, cocoa, etc. Ms. F. offers the mill service every day from early hours in the morning until dusk. It is important to emphasize also that she is a very hard-working woman. She is committed to the well-being of her son since she is a single mother and has to support her young child's studies and also provide for the household necessities. With the loan that she hopes for from Ceprodel, she will be able to buy tools for the mill machinery in order to offer a better service.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tools for the mill service for food

loans.name: Chadulu H Group

texts.en:
Josephine has been a vegetable seller in the Ipagala neighborhood of Dodoma for four years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory for her business, increase her sales, and pay school fees for her children.

Josephine is 37 years old, married, and has five children who are between the ages of 28 and 6. She also takes care of another child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Sabina, Colletha, Zainabu, and Pili. Each woman also has her own small business in Iringa.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell in her business.

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr: Essi T. est  âgée de 41 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants tous à l’école. Elle tient une baraque au bord de la route sur laquelle elle étale divers articles. Elle désire avec ce crédit augmenter la aille de son commerce en louant un magasin et en l’approvisionnant de  diverses marchandises. Ceci lui permettra de mieux répondre aux besoins de la clientèle et par là augmenter ses recettes pour mieux épargner.
texts.en:
Essi T. is 41 years old, married, and the mother of three children, who are all in school. She has a road-side stand where she displays various goods. She would like to use this loan to expand her commerce by renting out a store and supplying it with diverse merchandise. This will enable her to meet the needs of her customers better and thus to increase her receipts, so that she may save more money.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To rent a store and supply it with merchandise

loans.name: Mr. Sarum Prak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank which consists of fifteen people is located in Trapang Kda village in Kampong Chhnang province and all the members will use the loan for a different purpose. Mr. Sarum P. is a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it so he decided to ask for a loan to buy three more piglets for breeding. His wife, Mrs. Sok Than, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Mr. Sarum P. is 50 years old and the father of four children, one of whom is working in a garment factory while the remaining three are attending the local school.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Twelve members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These clients are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy three more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng K., 32, is married and resides with her husband and three children in the Siem Reap province. To earn a living, she sells fish in the local market. She earns approximately US$5 per day. Her husband pictured here, works as a farmer. He grows rice two times a year and makes US$8 per day. Two of their children are in school and one is too young to attend. To expand cultivation, Seng K. has requested a loan to purchase land and fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase land and fertilizer.

loans.name: Geralyn

texts.en:
Geralyn O. is a pig grower. She has a piggery in her backyard since 1998. She is 29 years old and has two children who are all in school. She meets the needs of her family by raising pigs. Her husband is a farmer, and she thinks that along with her husband’s income, she needs to contribute something to increase her family income. She is asking a loan of PHP 10,000 from CEVI to buy feed for her pigs. She will also use a part of the loan to buy fertilizers for her rice farm.

CEVI is helping Geralyn obtain feed for her pigs. Now, Geralyn has access to credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage that CEVI gives to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs and purchase fertilizers for her rice farm

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Marie A. est une jeune femme de 40 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. elle est revendeuse de charbons de bois, la principale source d’énergie utilisée dans les foyers. Ce commerce est très florissant à cause de la demande sans cesse croissante.  Avec ce crédit, Marie souhaite se ravitailler en charbons de bois afin de répondre aux demandes de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Marie A. is a young woman, 40 years old, married, and the mother of four. She sells charcoal, the main source of energy used in homes. Business is booming because of the ever-growing demand. With this loan, Marie would like to resupply herself with charcoal in order to respond to customer demands.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is 44 years old and has six children. She is married to O. who is a dock worker at the sea port. Rosemary sells drinks and pepper soup. Rosemary hopes for a loan of  N50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 35 years old and is a resident of Barangay Natappian West Solana in Solana, Cagayan. She has five children. The first three are attending school, while two of them are still young. She is married to Marcelo I., who is a driver in their village. Janet and Marcelo help each other for the progress of their lives.

Janet operates a village store to help her husband provide for their family and send their children to school. She is requesting a loan of PHP 23,000 as additional working capital to grow her general store. She wakes up as early as she can to open the store and does not close until 8 p.m. to earn as much profit as she possibly can. The couple tries hard in order to give their children better lives in the future.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Salustio

texts.es:
El señor Salustio Pérez vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Las Lomas, área periférica de la ciudad de La Paz, con su hermano.
El señor Salustio trabaja como electricista, realizando instalaciones en viviendas particulares.
Con anteriores préstamos realizo la construcción de su vivienda en obra gruesa, la que ya tiene habilitado un dormitorio en el que actualmente vive.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de una sala, mas una cocina, en su vivienda.
Esta es la cuarta vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Salustio Pérez lives in his own home in the Las Lomas zone, an area adjacent to the city of La Paz with his brother. Salustio works as an electrician, carrying out installations in individual homes. With previous loans he had carried out mayor construction on his home and has built a room in which he currently lives. The loan that he is requesting is to start construction on a living room and a kitchen in his home. This is the fourth time that he has requested a loan and because he has favorably met the financial analysis criteria he has been approved for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To start construction on a living room and a kitchen in his home to be able to live more comfortably.

loans.name: Luisa Marina

texts.es: Luisa Marina F. A. de 43 años de edad reside en Atiquizaya junto a  sus dos hijas. Ella posee una venta de tamales, panes con pollo, yuca frita, papas fritas y otros platillos típicos salvadoreños. Luisa posee una reputación muy buena ya que es una mujer muy responsable la cual trabaja muy duro por darles una mejor vida a sus hijas. Ella solicita un préstamo ya que necesita comprar pollo, carne, maíz, y otros ingredientes más para la realización de sus platillos.
texts.en:
Luisa Marina F. A. is 43. She lives in Atiquizaya with her two daughters. She sells tamales, breads with chicken, fried yucca, fried potatoes, and other typical Salvadorian dishes. Luisa has a very good reputation because she is a very responsible woman. She works very hard to give her daughters a better life. She is asking for a loan because she needs to buy chicken, meat, corn, and other ingredients to make her dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raw material to make her typical dishes

loans.name: Sáu

texts.en:
Sáu N. Thị (1112060366) is a 47-year-old woman living in the town of Kim Động. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Sáu owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food products in the local community. Sáu has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2003, Sáu joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sáu has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Sáu is now requesting a new loan of 20000000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. Sáu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: Used to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rosa Blanca Group

texts.es:
El grupo Rosa Blanca está conformado por  María Esther S., Mercedes G. M. y Emérita G. Hernández, ellas habitan  en la comarca Altos que es una zona rural que pertenece al municipio de Nindirí.
La coordinadora del grupo es la señora María Esther S. de 45 años de edad ella tiene cinco hijos de las siguientes edades 25, 24, 22, 20 y 17 años respectivamente de estos solo los tres últimos se encuentran con ella y están estudiando.  S. empezó en el negocio de la repostería desde muy pequeña junto con su madre quien fue la que le enseño  este negocio al que ella empezó a tomarle cariño. 

Actualmente ella trabaja junto con sus hijos en la realización de repostería y necesita invertir en la compra de materia prima como son la harina, huevo, leche, polvo para hornear, mantequilla, levadura y colorantes. El mayor anhelo de S. es tener la pastelería en unas instalaciones adecuadas. 

Las otras integrantes del grupo son Mercedes G. M. de 45 años. El negocio de esta señora es el destace de cerdo del cual  vende la carne y  produce  frito de cerdo,  chicharrón,  moronga y  nacatamales (masa, carne de cerdo, tomate, arroz, papa, chile, y cebolla) que son comidas tradicionales nicaragüenses.

Mientras doña Emérita G. Hernández de 43 años de edad tiene una pequeña pulpería bien surtida con los productos de consumo diario como el arroz, los frijoles, el maíz entre otros.

El grupo Rosa Blanca ya ha recibido préstamos en adim lo que les permitió incrementar la producción y contar con el capital para reinvertir pero actualmente sus negocios demanda mayor inversión. Es por esta razón que estas señoras luchadoras, emprendedoras y trabajadoras pero de muy escasos recursos económicos desean obtener un nuevo préstamo para así poder contar con un capital para invertir en sus respectivos negocios y lograr que estos sean más productivos.
texts.en:
The White Rose group consists of María Esther S., Mercedes G. M. and Emérita G. Hernández. They live in the Altos region, a rural area in Nindirí province. The coordinator of the group is 45 year old María Esther S.. She has 5 children ages 25, 24, 22, 20 and 17 years old, of whom the youngest three are still with her and studying in school. She began a bakery business at a young age with her mother who taught her this business and María really enjoys it. Today she works with her children in the bakery and needs to invest in buying ingredients such as flour, eggs, milk, baking powder, butter, yeast, and food coloring. Her greatest goal is having an adequate locale for her bakery business. The other members of the group include Mercedes G. M.. She is 45 years old and raises pigs which she sells for meat and makes fried pork, chicharrón (fried skin), moronga, and nacatamales (corn meal, pork, tomatoe, rice, potato, chile, and onion) – all are traditional Nicaraguan dishes. Meanwhile 43 year old Emérita G. Hernández has her own convenience store, well stocked with items used daily such as rice, beans, corn, and more. The White Rose group has received ADIM loans which have enabled them to increase production and have the capital to invest but in reality their businesses need more investment. For this reason these fighting, hard-working women of few resources wish to obtain a loan in order to be able to have the capital to invest in their respective businesses and make them more productive and successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients such as flour, eggs, milk, baking powder, butter, yeast, and food coloring to use in the bakery

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 66 year old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Ali has owned a grocery store for nineteen years. Ali requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise. This is his third cycle and he has always on time. 
Ali is special in his work because he knows how to treat his client. His clients are family members, friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash, as well as not a lot of passer-bys. Ali decided on doing his business because he used to work as a furniture painter but he didn’t like it and he also wanted to have an independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Achat de bois de chauffage

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle K. is from the village of P-4, Brgy. 25, Pandan, Gingoog City.  She is 27 years old. Michelle is single and has four school-age children. To make a living, Michelle owns and operates a retail clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general clothing services to local community members with her "ukay-ukay" store. Michelle has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Michelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Michelle is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and also for working capital.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

location.town: Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City, Mis. Or.

loans.name: Grace Group

texts.en:
“Grace” is a group of five borrowers led by Fatu T., a  33-year-old married woman. Fatu has three children aged 9 to 14 years old and their educational levels are 2nd through 7th grade.

Fatu is illiterate because she is a victim of the belief that only men should be educated and women should be taken care of by their husbands. She lives in New Kru Town, a crowded and poor community north of the Monrovia, the capital of Liberia, that is full of crime. She works in the Dualla Market, a big market where farmers brings their goods from out of town to sell.

Fatu's business is selling used clothing. She buys used clothing wholesale and sells it in the Dualla Market. She has been running this business for ten years and hopes to own a boutique in the future. Fatu sells quality products so that customers can be encouraged to always come back and buy more from her.

Fatu needs this loan in order to purchase more goods. She dreams of building a house for herself and her family and to totally change her family’s life.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing to sell

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is a village store owner. She is married; her husband cultivates their small farm lot by planting rice and some vegetables. Due to high cost of commodities, Beatriz wants to acquire more products but cannot do so because she lacks business capital. Consequently, she wants to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 8,000.00. She will use the money to purchase more goods. She believes that this will enable her to improve her small "sari-sari" (variety) store and earn a higher income.

As parents, Beatriz and her husband are concerned with the future of their children. They sacrifice their time to support the needs of their four children, who are studying in tertiary and secondary education.

loans.use: improving her "sari-sari" (variety) store

loans.name: Angel Fernando

texts.es:
Angel  vive en la calle “ Vega ”  de la zona Villa Dolores en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Vive en casa propia,  junto a su esposa la cual es comerciante en un mercado de la zona  y  sus dos hijos menores.
 
Trabaja como maestro carpintero en su taller ubicado en el centro de la ciudad de La Paz.
 
El crédito lo destinará en la adquisición de madera al por mayor, ya que para su trabajo requiere que el material este relativamente seco.
 
Es el   octavo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Angel lives on Vega Street in the Villa Dolores zone of El Alto city. He lives in his own house with his wife and two children. She is a merchant in the public market. He works as a master carpenter with his own shop, located in the center of the city of La Paz.

The loan is destined for the acquisition of wood at wholesale. For his work the material must be relatively dry. This is his 8th loan from IMPRO. The evaluation carried out shows him to be qualified to receive the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY WOOD FOR HIS CARPENTER SHOP

loans.name: Rose

texts.fr: T. Rose est née le 23 Août 1974 et est mariée à LAWANI Rafiou, un frigoriste. Rose est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble depuis neuf ans au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rose supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille. Rose a été à l’école jusqu’au secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Rose vend des produits divers (huile d’arachide, huile de palme, savons, omo, conserves, lait, pâtes alimentaires, sucre, riz, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Rose fait ses achats. Rose mène cette activité depuis sept ans déjà et est à son quatrième crédit. C’est une cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de satisfaire la demande nombreuse de ses clients, Rose sollicite auprès de ALIDé un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
T. Rose was born on Auguest 23, 1974 and is married to LAWANI Rafiou, a refrigeration specialist.  She is the mother of two children who are both in school.  For nine years, the family has lived together in the Kpondéhou district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Along with her husband, she provides for the family. Rose has attended secondary school.  To provide for herself, she sells a variety of goods (peanut oil, palm oil, soaps, Omo, canned foods, milk, pasta, sugar, rice, etc.) out of her home.  Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she makes her purchases.  Rose has been in this business for seven years already and is on her fourth loan.  She is an ALIDé client who repays her loans.  To increase her working capital and to satisfy the numerous demands of her customers, she's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of pasta, containers of peanut oil and palm oil, soaps, Omo, sacks of rice, and sugar

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 33 years old and married with two children. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a friendly woman, and she uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her salon. She makes lovely hair styles for her customers, and she also sells hair extensions and cream. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Julie's Group

texts.en:
Julie L. is from the city of Capatan Tuguegarao. She is 49 years old. Julie is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Capatan Group".

Julie is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Julie owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling ice cream to the local community. Julie is just starting this business.

In 2009, Julie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Julie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima S. is from the town of Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 59 years old. Maxima is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Maxima owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maxima has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Maxima joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maxima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. Maxima is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Maxima from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna P., 46 years old, owns a small rice farm. A mother of seven children, her eldest child, 26, helps her grow rice. The income that her family makes from this enterprise really helps pay the daily expenses in their home. Because she desires a good life, Myra is doing the very best she can to maximize the harvest and earn a better income. A farmer for many years now, she hopes to make her business more prosperous and buy another farm in the future. Myrna is now requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. which she will use to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Filipina

texts.en:
Filipina C. is a single, 61-year-old woman from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. To make a living, Filipina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP every four months from these activities.
In 2008, Filipina joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. Filipina is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda B., from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya, is 49 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a general store that sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over four years, earning approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP that was used to purchase additional products to sell, Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase new items to expand the store's product offerings. This loan will be her second from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the store to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
